1. A particle of mass 0.8 kg is moving in a straight line on a rough horizontal plane. The
speed of the particle is reduced from 15ms7? to 10ms" as the particle moves 20 m.
Assuming that the only resistance to motion is the friction between the particle and the
plane, find

(a) the work done by friction in reducing the speed of the particle from 15ms! to

10ms',
(2)
(b) the coefficient of friction between the particle and the plane.
(4)

2. Acar of mass 800kg is moving at a constant speed of 15ms down a straight road
inclined at an angle a to the horizontal, where sin a = 77. The resistance to motion from
non-gravitational forces is modelled as a constant force of magnitude 900 N.

(a) Find, in kW, the rate of working of the engine of the car.
(4)
When the car is travelling down the road at 15 ms", the engine is switched off. The car

comes to rest in time 7 seconds after the engine is switched off. The resistance to motion
from non-gravitational forces is again modelled as a constant force of magnitude 900 N.

(b) Find the value of T.
(4)

3. Figure 1

Figure 1 shows a template T made by removing a circular disc, of centre X and radius
8cm, from a uniform circular lamina, of centre O and radius 24cm. The point X lies on
the diameter AOB of the lamina and AX = 16cm. The centre of mass of 7 is at the
point G.

(a) Find AG.
(6)

The template Tis free to rotate about a smooth fixed horizontal axis, perpendicular to the
plane of 7, which passes through the mid-point of OB. A small stud of mass +m is fixed
at B, and T and the stud are in equilibrium with AB horizontal. Modelling the stud as a
particle,

(b) find the mass of 7 in terms of m.

(4)

4. Aparticle P of mass m is moving in a straight line on a smooth horizontal table. Another
particle O of mass Am is at rest on the table. The particle P collides directly with QO. The
direction of motion of P is reversed by the collision. After the collision, the speed of P is
v and the speed of Q is 3v. The coefficient of restitution between P and Q is $.

(a) Find, in terms of v only, the speed of P before the collision.

(3)

(b) Find the value of k.

(3)
After being struck by P, the particle Q collides directly with a particle R of mass llm
which is at rest on the table. After this second collision, Q and R have the same speed and

are moving i opposite directions. Show that

(c) the coefficient of restitution between Q and R is 3,
(4)

(d) there will be a further collision between P and QO.

5. | Figure 2

A horizontal uniform rod AB has mass m and length 4a. The end A rests against a rough
vertical wall. A particle of mass 2m is attached to the rod at the point C, where AC = 3a.
One end of a light inextensible string BD is attached to the rod at B and the other end is
attached to the wall at a point D, where D is vertically above 4. The rod is in equilibrium
in a vertical plane perpendicular to the wall. The string is inclined at an angle 0 to the
horizontal, where tan @ =2, as shown in Figure 2.

(a) Find the tension in the string.

(5)

(b) Show that the horizontal component of the force exerted by the wall on the rod has
magnitude 2 mg.

(3)

The coefficient of friction between the wall and the rod is yu. Given that the rod is in
limiting equilibrium,

(c) find the value of yu.

(2)

(b) Show that, when ¢ = 3, the velocity of P is (91+ 15j) ms".
(5)

velocity of P is (-3i+ 20j)ms"!. Find
